    Forest imputation

    impute_forests.Rd

    Performs imputation of forest objects from a forest inventory using a forest class map to match composition and topography as covariates.

    impute_forests(
  x,
  sf_nfi,
  dem,
  forest_map,
  varClass,
  replace_existing = FALSE,
  empty_forests = TRUE,
  merge_trees = TRUE,
  merge_shrubs = TRUE,
  verbose = TRUE
)

    Arguments

    x

    An object of class sf

    sf_nfi

    An object of class sf with forest inventory data column 'forest'

    dem

    A digital elevation model (class rast) with meters as units

    forest_map

    An object of class rast or vect with the forest class map

    varClass

    Variable name or index containing forest classes in 'forest_map'

    replace_existing

    A logical flag to force the replacement of existing 'forest' objects, when present

    empty_forests

    A logical flag to place empty 'forest' objects for wildland cells not having a forest class

    merge_trees

    A logical flag to simplify tree cohorts by merging tree records in DBH classes (see forest_mergeTrees)

    merge_shrubs

    A logical flag to simplify shrub cohorts by merging shrub records in height classes (see forest_mergeShrubs)

    verbose

    A logical flag to print console output.

    Value

    A modified object of class sf with column 'forest'.

    Details

    The function performs a simplistic imputation of forest inventory plots on target locations provided that they correspond to the same forest class, defined in the forest map. Among the multiple stands that can have the target forest class, the function chooses the one that has the most similar elevation and position in the N-to-S slopes (i.e. the product of the cosine of aspect and slope). Both topographic features are standardized to zero mean and unit standard deviation, to make their influence on the imputation equal. This imputation method will be more or less successful depending on the resolution of forest classes and the number of forest inventory plots available for each of them.

    Examples

    if (FALSE) {
  # See vignette 'Landscape inputs'
}
